instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image after screen repair
threads.message:
I was changing the screen and think something with the screen was wrong. I witnessed L8300 turn bright red and blow.  I changed it and watched it blow again. I did this about 3 times (it was pretty cool).
I have tried multiple know good screens (brand new) and don't get any image.

Looks like the only voltage I get is 1.5V on pin 12.
I get 5V on pins 2&3 on <CHIP>U8300</CHIP> but that is it.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image after screen repair
threads.message: There is a short power burst on L8300 (5V I think) at startup.

threads.message: FL8300-FL8303 have continuity. L8300 good. Caps <CAPACITOR>C8320</CAPACITOR> & look good and present.

threads.message:
Don't use comments I don't see them.

If there is 5V on both sides and there is an image it must work. I doubt it will cause video garbage, but anything is possible.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image after screen repair
threads.message:
OK.  I changed L8300.  Out of the several screens that I was testing with, the one that had a distorted image is actually good when I used the good L8300.
You can close this mystery out ! A bad L8300 can cause a distorted image.  I thought L8300 was good because it had continuity.  L8300 is an inductor? Like a coil? 

I didn't know that you couldn't see comments, that is weird. I will post them below.
Comments: 
FL8300-FL8303 have continuity. L8300 good. Caps <CAPACITOR>C8320</CAPACITOR> & look good and present.
So it can have continuity and still be bad? 
Would a bad L8300 cause a distorted image on the screen?
Or would it not allow the screen to be "seen?" 
Thank you Duke

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image after screen repair
threads.message:
This is absolutely not needed for board repair, but let's make it more confusing:)

Equivalent circuit of ferrite inductor is a resistor and a coil in series. R in series with L.
The symbol used in the industry is L wether it s a coil, a filter, a ferrite bead, inductor...
220 ohm mentioned in schematic for L8300 is not a resistor value it is an impedance value.
Impedance is a complex number that contains two parts: the resistance (R in ohms) is the real part and the reactance (X in ohms, X=2PifL) is the imaginary part.

Usually industry uses only impedance and dc current range for ferrite.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image after screen repair
threads.message:
[QUOTE="jadao, post: 20203"]This is absolutely not needed for board repair, but let's make it more confusing:)

Equivalent circuit of ferrite inductor is a resistor and a coil in series. R in series with L.
The symbol used in the industry is L wether it s a coil, a filter, a ferrite bead, inductor...
220 ohm mentioned in schematic for L8300 is not a resistor value it is an impedance value.
Impedance is a complex number that contains two parts: the resistance (R in ohms) is the real part and the reactance (X in ohms, X=2PifL) is the imaginary part.

Usually industry uses only impedance and dc current range for ferrite.[/QUOTE]

Basically it's not a DC resistance and you can't throw a resistor in it's place.

Donor boards here:

[url]https://www.aliexpress.com/store/product/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A-Faulty-logic-board-for-Macbook-Pro-Retina-15-<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-repair/1596219_32611298760.html[/url]

threads.title: [SOLVED]<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No image after screen repair
threads.message: [B]Jadao, G. Beard, and Duke. Thank you guys for the explanations simplified.  I can Google this stuff all day and still won't make sense.  Even these answers are a bit confusing, I'll have to reread and ponder on them a bit for it to make sense.  I did some experimenting and just went ahead and put one of these resistors (or whatever in hell they are -LOL) in and it worked!  I already have a pile of donor boards and pulled all these filters off already. I do get them from DHGate & AliExpress : )  I always knew I could put a wire in place of a filter like on iPad and iPhone. I thought that maybe there would be a difference in a MacBook. Nonetheless, I have been getting out of that habit and putting the proper components in their place because if something happens I'd like to have the fuse blow instead of passing through a wire and damaging something else.  I am thankful for your guys's feedback !  You can close this one out : ) [/B]
